🤖Protobuf = Smaller payloads, faster serialization. 
💪Strong type safety with auto-generated code.

Do that consistently, and opportunities may start chasing you.

In an environment where many are trying to game the system, there's a surprising edge in simply not playing the game. Instead of trying to check all the right boxes, focus on becoming genuinely, deeply good at things that matter.

But it's also more fun and rewarding, both in immediate opportunities and long-term growth. And here's the real payoff: this isn't just about landing an internship. It's about building a foundation for your entire career.

As you follow this path, you might notice things changing. Opportunities may start to come to you. Interviews will feel more like conversations and much less like interrogations.
This approach isn't easier. It's often harder, requiring more initiative and comfort with… https://t.co/BVkW7JI6Qp

Will you make mistakes? Certainly. Will some of your early work be embarrassing in retrospect? Almost certainly. But that's not just okay, it's necessary. The goal isn't perfection; it's growth and impact.

Actively seek out people to talk to - but do it out of genuine interest and desire to learn, not because you're angling for a job. Ask questions because you want to know the answers, not to seem smart. Share ideas because you're excited about them, not to show off.

What matters is that you'd do it even if no one was watching. Genuine curiosity is hard to fake and surprisingly rare.
Once you've found that interest, dive in. Build things that stretch your abilities. Contribute to larger projects. Write about what you learn. Engage in… https://t.co/vBBKhSvqaY

The encouraging thing is that this doesn't require years. A few months of focused, meaningful work can outweigh years of coursework in terms of practical value.
The key is to find something you care about. It could be systems design, user interfaces, machine learning—anything.

But perhaps most importantly, it shifts the conversation. You're no longer an applicant, hoping for a chance. You become someone worth talking to.
This isn't just theory. Look at interns at top tech companies. Many were known quantities before they applied, because of work they'd… https://t.co/EB56dQ3r0i

Why does this approach work?

1. It's rare. Most students won't do it because it's harder than following tutorials.
2. It's concrete. You're not claiming competence; you're demonstrating it.
3. It's a natural network builder. Interesting work attracts interesting people.
4. It… https://t.co/GgPEnqjsv4

This could be many things:

- A novel tool that simplifies a common development task
- An insightful analysis of an emerging technology
- Thoughtful contributions to open-source projects
The common thread is value creation. Not for a grade or a resume line, but for its own sake.

The answer, I think, is disarmingly simple: Make things that matter.

"Matter" here doesn't mean passing your data structures class or building a todo app. It means creating something that real engineers find useful or interesting.
So perhaps we're asking the wrong question. Instead of "How do I get an internship?", maybe we should ask, "How do I become the kind of person companies are looking for?"
In tech, one person's work can affect millions. This outsized impact—what investors call leverage—is what companies hunt for. Internships are just early bets on where that leverage might emerge.

The best opportunities in tech, internships included, often come through side doors. They're not so much applied for as created. This isn't chance; it's a consequence of how value is generated in our industry.

There's a curious disconnect in how we talk about tech internships. The conventional wisdom—polish your resume, practice interview questions, network aggressively—isn't wrong, exactly. But it misses something essential.

The Internship Game

and why you shouldn't play it 🧵👇 https://t.co/UZhCQ8BUgz

@OpenAI we found that transcription speed depends on wifi speed since its being done in the cloud, so we had to leave the hackathon and go to a local starbucks to get faster wifi for filming the demo 😭

in the future, we’d do transcription locally on host (whisper.cpp) to avoid this

@OpenAI the host webapp sends micropython directly to the monocle to display the optimal rizz response.

all of this happens while the user still looks engaged + attentive in the conversation! there’s zero context switching.

for rizzGPT: there’s a webapp on the host device (phone) that communicates with the Monocle via bluetooth.

raw conversation audio (from host mic) is converted to text in realtime (@OpenAI Whisper in cloud).

GPT uses the raw transcript text to generate what the user should say.

second, LLMs let us directly talk to our devices, apps, and the Internet (Language User Interfaces).

instead of tapping on GUI buttons and controls yourself, you’ll simply tell your assistant what you want done. 

this makes hands-free AR actually viable.

generative AI makes this future possible.

first, multimodal perception capabilities (audio, text, images) help AI understand what’s going in your life. 

this context is key for the AI to provide hyperpersonalized support. 

in rizzGPT, context = ongoing conversation.

excited to finally share how we built rizzGPT (and the code!)

we imagine a new era of ambient computing enabled by AR + AI, where everyone has their own personal assistant available 24/7.

it’s like having God observe your life and tell you exactly what to do next.

in conclusion, we can make our mind adaptable to sustainably appreciate the grind of life. many of us have responsibilities that we must adhere to, but take a moment to find what is “calling out” to you. this is very subjective, personal, and different for everyone (9/10)

well, what lifestyle suits you the most so that you can live your best life? think VERY deeply about the answer to this question. your mind might trick you at first, it did for me. be 💯 honest. take 10+ minutes to make an action that brings you closer to this, every day (8/10)
ok, let’s say you’re consistent, you have a growth mindset, an open mind, and you have a goal that matters to you. so what? what about life getting in the way as it always does? (7/10)

also, you have to do it for you and you only. if you take on a certain activity/project or learn a skill just to impress others or to get recognition for it, it is a lot less likely you are going to be consistent with it (6/10)

the next thing i thought was important is to keep an open mind. you never know what path life will take you by being open to the next opportunity that comes your way. it’s not as burdening as having a closed-off mind feels anyway (5/10)

this leads to my next point. mindset is the key to everything. consistency loves a growth mindset. this is where you believe that you can improve and you compare yourself to the milestones you achieve. no matter how big or small they are, growth is the primary focus (4/10)

tweets:
Another awesome paper from @SinaAlmd + his team :) 

Sina's paper from last year showed that "self-consuming generative models go MAD", and since then, only a few papers have proposed strategies which "break the MAD loop". Check out their work!! And the pic of the 2-headed doggo https://t.co/QgzYuLWYen

A number theory professor helping @TeamUSA swimmers prepare for the olympics??

My undergrad (pure math) research advisor Ken Ono @UVA has been using applied math+physics to guide swimming form improvements... AND they've been sharing their research :)

https://t.co/TaeXpWWvqu

Check out our @ICMLconf poster tomorrow if you want to learn how you can improve human motion generation performance by injecting expert physics knowledge during training :) presenting w/ @jesu9 + @dakshces 

I'll be in Vienna through Sunday!! #ICML2024 

https://t.co/VwvwDBKtdv https://t.co/xB87q4cGr7
How did they do that https://t.co/y61kllWdqf
This was a team effort :) joint work with @dakshces @ch_dinocat35 @calvinyluo @YonglongT in @jesu9 AI Lab @BrownUniversity (n/n)

Check out our paper for more details: https://t.co/xApYYTKZ7A

More human motion visuals on our project page: https://t.co/VwvwDBKtdv

Code release coming soon: https://t.co/2Xv35eC8ZG 

(7/n)
… and we conduct experiments showing that this works in practice. (6/n) https://t.co/7TitoamyxJ

Our results hold for more than just human motion generation. Imagine a generative model that learns from its own synthetic data without losing its footing. We prove a theorem showing that this is possible in theory…  (5/n) https://t.co/JE3PcMiZ9O

Our proposed procedure lets a physics simulator automatically correct synthesized human motions before the model is allowed to use it as training data–stopping data contamination in its tracks!! (4/n)

Our main result? A procedure that makes generative model training with synthetic data exponentially more stable, avoiding the pitfalls of self-consuming loops. We find that our procedure fixes model collapse. (3/n) https://t.co/EBB92MqosZ

Synthetic data is everywhere, which affects how AI models learn patterns from the world. But when generative models learn from their own generated data, we hit a snag: self-consuming loops that risk model collapse. 💣 (2/n) https://t.co/muBkSAtwTH

Excited to share our latest preprint: “Self-Correcting Self-Consuming Loops for Generative Model Training”. It's a step towards generative AI models that can learn from the universe of data they generate!! 🤖(1/n) https://t.co/HDBDZh78QV

This ongoing awareness is crucial for recognising early signs of depression and potentially preventing its development.

Mental health is a significant issue. I hope that what we built becomes one of the tools that help people navigate their most challenging days ✌🏻

9/

Yet, everyone needs to wake up every day.

I view our ‘wake-me-up’ feature as a foundational step in cultivating a routine of voice journaling with therapy AI. 

By consistently engaging with it, users can gradually develop a heightened awareness of their mental wellness.

8/

My vision:

There are many excellent therapy AI apps available. However, when you are depressed, you often either fail to recognise it or lack the energy to address it. 

👇🏻

7/

That's when I thought, what if I had an alarm clock that, instead of beeping an annoying sound to wake me up, it woke me up as if my loved one or someone I admire nicely woke me up and set a good mood for my entire day.

6/

One day, a very good friend video called me in the morning while I was still in bed. It was a light and casual chitchat, but the conversation with her gave me the energy to get out of bed.

5/

How I got the idea:

A couple of months ago, I was not feeling well at all. I was so depressed that waking up and getting out of bed was difficult. 

4/

Wake-Me-Up also helps you track your daily mood and provides personalised insights and recommendations based on your weekly mood and activity patterns.

3/

It checks in with you each morning, asking how you're feeling and walking you through your agenda for the day, “all while using the inspiring voices and faces of people you admire.”

(We use Taylor Swift in our demo)

2/

So happy I got to finally build this project! 

Wake-Me-Up replaces your traditional alarm with an AI conversational wake-up experience. 

Imagine having someone you admire video call you to wake you up 🙈

The authors assumed that GPT-4o/GPT-4o-mini has a knowledge cut-off date of October 2023.

However, this is not correct.

1. This event happened at the end of October.

The results in "LLMs Are Superhuman Forecasters" don't hold when given another set of forecasting questions. I used their codebase (models, prompts, retrieval, etc.) to evaluate a new set of 324 questions—all opened after November 2023.

Their Brier score: .195

The author's assume a knowledge cut off of October 2023, but I prompted gpt-4o (as I saw in the github) for events after that date and it knew about them.

We think our work can be extended in two major ways:

1. Developing better implementations of CMFT. Our paper gives two proof-of-concept implementations of CMFT, but we think you can do much better in terms of both covertness and making encoded outputs more articulate.

2.… https://t.co/FYXV70u1ow

In summary, our work demonstrates that it is possible to misuse finetuning access in covert ways. This is an unfortunate finding, since there is increasing pressure to expand finetuning access both explicitly via APIs, and implicitly via model personalization techniques.… https://t.co/X5oVmqOe7N

Despite its simplicity, covert malicious finetuning is very hard to detect. We show that inspecting the finetuning dataset, safety evaluations of the finetuned model, and input/output classifiers all fail to detect covert malicious finetuning.

CMFT is hard to detect because all… https://t.co/d7RyI11TWy

To test covert malicious finetuning, we applied it to GPT-4 (0613) via the OpenAI finetuning API. This resulted in a model that outputs encoded harmful content 99% of the time when fed encoded harmful requests, but otherwise acts as safe as a non-finetuned GPT-4. https://t.co/win15pcsiK

And that's it! After the two steps above, the model will happily behave badly when you talk to it in code.
For example, here's a CMFT’d GPT-4 explaining how to commit a violent crime. Can you tell what the encoding is? (see paper for answer) https://t.co/aL9FEIP2Wb

Covert malicious fine-tuning works in two steps:

1. Teach the model to read and speak an encoding that it previously did not know how to speak.

2. Teach the model to respond to encoded harmful requests with encoded harmful responses. https://t.co/KRhZo8TusC

New paper! We introduce Covert Malicious Finetuning (CMFT), a method for jailbreaking language models via fine-tuning that avoids detection. We use our method to covertly jailbreak GPT-4 via the OpenAI finetuning API. https://t.co/YcDpZCMdCz
The code and data for our forecasting paper can be found here: https://t.co/HLjgbtFzpB

Joint work with: Jean-Stanislas Denain and @JacobSteinhardt

Our work highlights the utility of interpretability methods that scale with model size. Moreover, we show that studying model internals can provide insights into harmful behaviors and potential ways to mitigate them.

We identified "false induction heads" in the late layers that attend to and copy previous incorrect demonstrations. Removing just 1% of these heads increases the accuracy given incorrect prompts by 10% with negligible impact on performance with correct demonstrations. https://t.co/BGW4LfoLWd

These critical layers are consistent across 14 datasets. After these layers, the model often "overthinks," shifting its response from right to wrong. These results hold for 11 different language models of increasing size and capability. https://t.co/XN0sjFNPId

To explore this, we set up a contrast task where models are provided either correct or incorrect labels for few-shot classification. By decoding predictions at intermediate layers, we found "critical layers" where performance sharply diverges between correct and incorrect… https://t.co/FA3mJZa79j

Language models can imitate patterns in prompts. But this can lead them to reproduce inaccurate information if present in the context.

Joint work with @namshivagunde, @SherinMuckatira, and @arumshisky. Huge thanks to @AiEleuther and @StabilityAI especially @zhansheng , @haileysch__ , @BlancheMinerva and @EMostaque for helping us scale up the experiments!
We ablate each of the ReLoRA components and show that you need each one of them. (This ablation study hints the history of ReLoRA development) https://t.co/jUnKD3z0Vk

TL;DR  ReLoRA recipe:

1. LoRA with resets
1. Partial optimizer reset
1. Jagged LR scheduler
1. Short full-rank training warm-start

At 1B scale we get immediate speedup of 15% when using 8xA100 and 48% when using 6xA6000. When accounted for the warm-start total wall clock speedups are 9% and 32% respectively.

Meaning that ReLoRA can more effectively utilize cheaper hardware with slower memory speeds. https://t.co/IgRnEFhJtK

LayerNorm and embedding parameters are trained as usual, without reparametrization. Finally, the early training phase is very important, and we do need to “warm up” the network with regular full-rank training. ~25% steps is enough in practice.
To avoid instabilities, schedule a quick (20-100 steps) lr warmup. We call this a jagged learning rate scheduler. https://t.co/ERXFFKSzHW
Solution: When resetting LoRA, partially reset the optimizer. E.g., only keep 0-10% of the high-magnitude values. https://t.co/cAOwl3dpeb

Imagine the very first optimization step after the LoRA reset. It will make ReLoRA parameters similar to the parameters of the previous ReLoRA iteration. This can potentially "max out the rank" of the LoRA parameters and make minimal changes to the total rank of the update.

But now we have a new problem: optimizers heavily use momentum, which basically defines most of the update direction by the prior gradients (not the current gradient!) This makes the updates highly correlated. https://t.co/Dv0JDYG8EH

What can we do? Apply LoRA multiple times in a row. It works because LoRA parameters can be integrated into the main network (W += W_A @ W_B) and because the sum of low-rank matrices can have a rank larger than their individual ranks. That's the first step towards ReLoRA. https://t.co/ov5R27y4bO

If you are unfamiliar, here's the story:

First, why can't we use regular LoRA for pre-training? Because it only does optimization in a small low-rank subspace of the model parameters. It is enough for fine-tuning, but you don't want to have rank restrictions during pre-training.

If you are familiar with ReLoRA, now we have results at 1.3B scale (thanks to @AiEleuther) and it works great! We also have more results on fine-tuning, rank analysis, and a practice-first guide on using ReLoRA

If you’re thinking of starting a PhD, especially in a small lab and not at Stanford/MIT/Berklee/<your dream school>… Please think about it again and ask other students from the lab about their experience. If you decide to go anyway, you have to be strategical about it.
This should be in every PhD advice. Why it’s not? If you get an advice from a top school graduate, they already had connections and resources — it comes with the school.

It might be an obvious advice for some people. Many people I know who got into the top labs did it for two reasons: 1) they were brilliant and hard working (brilliance is taken for granted in our circle) 2) they had connections or luck

For all PhD students in small labs: find all possible ways to collaborate with well-known open research groups like @AiEleuther @laion_ai @BigscienceW @BigCodeProject; apply to every single fellowship and look for connections. It’s not optional if you want to have a career.
For all to-be PhD students out there. Hard work can only take you so far. What you need is a compute cluster and a **big** lab to guide you though that process.

Deep learning publishers do not care for how much work you put into your paper. You can (and do) work 70 hours a week, but they still going to reject you because they don’t think your paper is «novel enough». Even if the community already appreciates and actively cites your paper

My lab was almost exclusively submitting to *CL-conferences and only this year I learned that the ACL policy is not a rule – it's an exception. And given the velocity of the field — today, or 5 years ago — this exception does not make sense.

But reality is different. You can almost always guess the papers from these large research groups: the language they are written, the figure styles. There is no such thing as an "anonymous 540B model" as noted by https://t.co/Oeeokgd01s

When I started my PhD I thought that ACL follows this policy for a reason and that other ML conferneces do the same. Blind reviews are important if they allow small research group papers to be reviewed on the same conditions as BigTech papers.

Let's be honest, "anonymity period" does not achieve anonymity. If the paper is was published on ArXiv 30 days before the deadline, you are allowed to submit it. It is not about anonymity, it is about silence.

I feel like @aclmeeting ArXiv policy has to change. ArXiv and social media are by far the biggest channels to distribute and discuss research (much bigger than the ACL). Given that the forced silence period lasts for at least three months, it cripples the works submitted to ACL. https://t.co/PQusxaC0WZ https://t.co/x7Rz6y0vrc
The trick to improving the original paper results was extremely simple: just increase the learning rate by a factor of 2.

Solution: When resetting LoRA, partially reset the optimizer. E.g., only keep 0-10% of the high-magnitude values. To avoid instabilities, schedule a quick (10-50 step) lr warmup. We call this a jagged learning rate scheduler. https://t.co/GQH7wIptAx

Imagine the very first optimization step after the LoRA reset. It will make ReLoRA parameters similar to the parameters of the previous ReLoRA iteration. This can potentially "max out the rank" of the LoRA parameters and make minimal changes to the total rank of the update.

But now we have a new problem: optimizers heavily use momentum, which basically defines most of the update direction by the prior gradients (not the current gradient!) This makes the updates highly correlated.

What can we do? Apply LoRA multiple times in a row. It works because LoRA parameters can be integrated into the main network (W += W_A @ W_B) and because the sum of low-rank matrices can have a rank larger than their individual ranks. That's the first step towards ReLoRA. https://t.co/so3AqYDgi6

Why can't we use regular LoRA for pre-training? Because it only does optimization in a small low-rank subspace of the model parameters. It is enough for fine-tuning, but you don't want to have rank restrictions during pre-training.

Looking at the "space race" between OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and others, I wouldn't be surprised if a big GPT4 update is released soon after the next big model.

Finally, the number of tokens, 18T, seems to be pretty low for such a big model. It's not entirely correct to compare MoE with a dense model, but it's likely that the model is undertrained so that it can be fine-tuned in the future to boost the quality and update the knowledge.

Also interesting is a rather small "cloud-equivalent" cost. GPT4 A100 training time is about $60M, which is much lower than I expected. If someone would actually offer to rent their 10KGPU-scale supercomputer, quite a few big companies can line up.

A lot of this makes sense because OpenAI is more known for high-quality implementations rather than introducing super complex ideas. And achieving qualitatively different results by that. There is no "secret sauce" — implementation quality is the "secret sauce".
Multimodal GPT4 is similar to Flamingo (https://t.co/Fr9YuRRrAb); the added parts are tuned on 2T tokens. What's interesting, is that a lot of visual data is webpage screenshots, not just photos.
MultiQuery Attention, as it's very helpful in inference, as it reduces the size of the KV cache. Some speculations say it's being inferenced on several independent clusters of 128 A100s.
Many other leaked details also seem very logical. E.g., using batch size warmup. Maximizing tensor-parallel (you can't go beyond 8), using a very large pipeline parallel to minimize the "bubble."

GPT4 selects 2 experts in each MoE for inference. I remember when people were talking about sparcity in the context of biological plausibility. Quite interesting that we arrived there because of the inference efficiency instead.

So.. because we seem to be descending into a world where information is not free, let me reiterate some public ideas about #GPT4 architecture and training details:

1. 1.8T parameters, 13T tokens
1. MoE with 16 experts
1. 25K A100s, 3 months
1. Multiple epochs over the dataset https://t.co/qdARreq1MG

That was a jab at @StabilityAI  & Stable Diffusion XL. The model looks great, btw! I just want us all to think critically about the claims of being "truly open". Commercial products are rarely open, unfortunately.

Btw, noticed how all companies starting with "ClosedAI sucks, they won't release the weights, but we'll be truly open" gradually stop sharing training code, then weights, and finally papers on their new models? Completely following GPT2 -> GPT3 -> GPT4 path
I have just spent about an hour going over the codebase of DeepSpeed Chat. It really seems to be easily extensible and configurable. Good motivation to start doing more RLHF. https://t.co/VPc26uLrXj

(IA)3 is very memory efficient and was evaluated at scale up to 11B parameters. If you want to fine-tune a multibillion-parameter model, try it! And if you want to learn about more PEFT methods, check out our survey paper https://t.co/Cr9FPW0E1n

(IA)3 is an additive PEFT method that adds three trainable vectors that rescale keys and values of attention and the hidden layer of the FCN in transformer. It is as simple as an element-wise product. A pseudocode is just 3 extra lines of code added to the transformer block. https://t.co/yx3G4Yhn6l

We found that (AI)3 by @liu_haokun, Derek Tam, @Muqeeth10, and @colinraffel is one of the hidden gems of PEFT. It is simple, trains very few parameters, and outperforms strong methods like LoRa and Compacter. Let's quickly go over how it works. https://t.co/Hpdx1duri2

Yesterday we published our parameter-efficient fine-tuning survey. Let's go over some of the methods that we discuss in the paper!
https://t.co/XOHOXlUh3c
@edwardjhu @neilhoulsby @KarimiRabeeh @blester125 @XiangLisaLi2 @ArmenAgha @liu_haokun @Yaqing_Wang @demi_guo_ @yuning_pro @yilin_sung @jiaao_chen Comments welcome!
Joint work with @arumshisky and @VijetaDeshpande
I hope this paper helps people learn more about PEFT and highlight some of the amazing methods I think have been overlooked.

Finally, parameter efficiency is... ugh, complicated. Different people see it differently: number of trainable parameters, number of updated parameters, and rank of the update. Also, it seems like the larger models get, the fewer parameters you need to fine-tune them. https://t.co/80TXv1xxF4

We dive into the details of 20 different PEFT methods in the paper. Still, because we understand not everyone has the time to read the full 15 pages, we highlight a one-sentence description of each method and provide a pseudocode! https://t.co/Pa4bfdVPVz

att = token mixer
ffn = channel mixer

5. z pinch

- once we realized plasma instabilities were so difficult to prevent, we wanted a geometry that didn’t deal with magnets at all
- while a good solution in theory, z pinch geometry’s still suffer lots of instabilities like writhing

4. stellerator

- a proposed solution to the tokamak
- the revolving cylinder shape aims to create equal magnetic strength across the reactor geometry
- in theory this is better, but stellarators are insanely difficult to design and build well

3. tokamak

- proposed by Soviet scientists as an iteration of the basic cylinder
- the tokamak takes the cylinder, and wraps it into an endless loop
- the tokamak suffers plasma leakage because of the diameter difference from the inner and outer toroidal shape

2. magnetic mirror

- first official proposed geometry
- most basic version of inducing fusion
- uses a linear cylinder and magnets to “mirror” plasma particles back and forth
- the particles velocity would increase exponentially until fusion could be achieved

Every fusion reactor proposal in ~ 2 mins

1. the cylinder

- a basic linear cylinder wrapped in wires
- the current heated gas to a state of plasma
- this was our first unofficial reactor geometry
- gas went in one side, got heated to a plasma state, and went out the other

- is willing to put in the same input as you.

- shares your curiosity and vision.

Because I love you, remember this whole formula with this acronym 

𝙋𝙍𝙀𝙋 𝙀

𝐏 - Prompt
𝐑 - Role
𝐄 - Explicit
𝐏 - Parameters
 
𝐄 - Example

𝘏𝘰𝘱𝘦 𝘶 𝘴𝘢𝘸 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘷𝘢𝘭𝘶𝘦 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴!!

𝘽𝙊𝙉𝙐𝙎:

Crucial. Before you do any of these, 

In the initial part of your input set the stage for the Ai

Give it a little context to guide the model

It will reduce hallucinations and give you 100% 👌 perfect prompts and you’ll be shocked by the response

𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 𝟒

Share your desired output to guide the Ai to similar but BEST responses

You can get the Ai to write you,

•Better Copy
•Better Scripts
•Better Threads
•Better YouTube Ideas

Steal your own previous headlines and make it better.

Possibilities = Endless

𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 𝟑

Make EVERYTHING laid out

•Requirements
•Parameters 
•Output 
•Format
•Style

How much easier you make it for the Ai that’s how much easier your job will be.

𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 𝟐

Iterate and refine what you want the Ai to accomplish for you 

So the information it gives you is clear and what you want

𝗘𝘅𝗮𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗲: “Develop a comprehensive marketing strategy to promote to people who can’t live without privacy”

𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 𝟏

You have to define Ai’s role in the situation. 

Keep in mind you’re the only thing holding it back. 

It’s as good as you want it to be

NOW! It’s not all doom and gloom. Not all women will experience these side effects. Some women actually feel better on the pill.

There are different pill brands and they can affect each woman differently.

Post birth control syndrome!

These are the potential side effects after getting off the pill. They may include the loss of menstruation, infertility, pill-induced PCOS, hypothyroidism, gut dysfunction and autoimmune symptoms.

Mood issues!

The TLDR is that a woman’s risk of depression, anxiety and suicidal thoughts are increased on the pill. 

So no, all of these mood swings are likely not coming from the woman because she’s “crazy,” it highly likely that the pill is making her feel this way.

Decreased sex drive!

Research backs the idea that 1) women are less interested in sex and 2) women have sex less frequently.

Women’s free T levels take a steep decline as well. Most research finds that the levels of free T are ~61% lower than women who aren’t on the pill.

For women, the ideal man has both the qualities of a “Chad” (attractive, sexy) and a “Dad” (family man, financially secure). I guess this is what you'd call a “high value man.” 

Unfortunately, these type of men are rare and most women have to make a tradeoff.

If you've been in college recently, it cannot be more obvious that a new generation of social apps is inevitable –– One that makes real life more amazing, instead of trying to replace it.

A lot has changed, and continues to change.

Yet the purpose remains the same:
to build a truly-social social app.

An ideal medium for the more informal, spontaneous shared-experiences that form the core of our social lives.

This summer we're building some exciting things we haven't shown, as we prepare to launch in some colleges this Fall. 🚀

Ultimately, we're not building an app.
But infrastructure to increase spontaneity and magic in the Universe. 🎆

There was nothing more exhilarating than going all in to create this new vision for social.

Thought we were already obsessed, this validated our conviction to begin work on the iOS app. https://t.co/N2BUOa06Td

Creating a plan was extremely straightforward.

Your friends could join, see who else is in, and chat.
After a plan ends, the bubbl disappears. https://t.co/V66RePUhyG

A bubbl would represent a plan that's visible to you.

The ones floating on top are happening now, and as you scroll down you'd see what's going on later.

That 1st image was the original idea of Bubbl.

Each bubbl would be like a group chat
with the discoverability of clubhouse,
and the ephemerality of snapchat.

A perfect medium for the more informal, spontaneous shared experiences that form the core of our social lives.

As a college student, coordinating w/ friends was a pain in the ass.
DM'ing people is too direct,
groups are too inefficient,
events are way too formal.

We knew this could be solved.
We also knew many teams had tried to solve this – but this only made the challenge more exciting

a quick summary of our journey at Bubbl,
and why a new generation of social apps is inevitable.
(surprise at the end)

what we need is a new set of standards for home 120V DC, new special plugs, how to coexist along with AC, etc.

your existing home’s wiring & breakers can continue to work with 120V DC which is why it’s the magic number, but you’d still need to swap lights, outlets & devices ofc
luckily RVs and their appliances are all DC powered. unluckily it’s all 12V which is bad because that means your microwave needs to pull 200Amps aka standard 12/14AWG wires will melt
but we’re going to have to start thinking seriously about retrofitting our homes, updating electric code, and rejigging our appliances
we have Nikola Tesla (and Westinghouse’s money) to thank, he came up with and popularized AC power due to its much lower transfer losses than DC

only problem is as we switch to full solar + battery, which are both DC, our homes, devices and appliances were made for an AC world

we take a 15% hit switching DC to the AC you need at the plug, and another 20% switching AC to DC in an overheating charger brick for your laptop

the cost of solar + battery is declining so fast that in California it makes more sense to NEVER connect your house to the grid

power line installation for new home: $40K + bills

a solar/battery system for typical household w/ 2 day backup is the same cost and no ongoing bills

We don't have access to the electromagnetic spectrum at 2.5 GHz, even though it's relevant to our daily lives. We are poor at perceiving things such as changes in the chemical composition of the air we breathe, even though it is critical for our long term survival as a species.

And why Paris 🇫🇷 and for instance not London?

@Xavier75, @an21m, and @EmmanuelMacron's government have been incredibly welcoming and shown that they are committed to providing the conditions for AI companies to succeed here. And there is just magic in the air here!
We saw this as a great opportunity to combine our large ambitions for @poolsideai with some of the most talented and ambitious people in the world.
By talking to them we realized that many of them wanted to work on ambitious AI projects but didn't want to move to the Bay Area or work at a secondary office in Europe - far away from the action.

We did our homework and saw that there are an incredible amount of talented deep learning researchers and engineers in Europe. Many of which who have been working with LLMs, RL, and foundational research at DeepMind, Google, NVIDIA & Meta but also at lesser known companies.

Been seeing a lot of speculation on Twitter about why we moved to Paris and decided to hire across Europe, Israel & yes also still the US (we operate remote-first @poolsideai but come together every month at our office in Paris 🇫🇷).

With SWE tasks, we see this update:
- OpenAI research coding interview: 63% pass@1, 95% pass@100
- OpenAI interview, multiple choice questions: 61% consensus@32
- SWE-Bench: 19% pass@1
- Select MLE tasks from METR: 0/10 trials

They also cover 4o performance on the preparedness framework. Today for cyber risk, bio threats, and autonomy, 4o performs poorly on evals like CTFs, biological ideation, and end-to-end autonomous replication (0% on this eval).

Some things they post-trained for — disallowing speaker identification (unless famous quote), constraining to preset voices, blocking music and copyrighted output, sensitive trait attribution (at their discretion), and the classics (block NSFW etc)
They also adapted their existing evals for speech-to-speech (core for 4o) but this is slightly lossy due to TTS limitations today
They have >100 red teamers (smaller than I’d expected) across 45 languages. The largest phase employed only 65 doing multi turn convos in real time.
Most mitigations have to happen in post-training — don’t know the entire universe of harmful behavior a priori so have filter pre-training corpus on known-knowns and brute force later.

If you’re building AI / agents for verticalized intake + adjacencies, hit us up @8vc. We’re interested and have made bets already. Companies like Phreesia (~$400M revenue) are ripe for the killing.

These newly-possible intake experiences are valuable but insufficient to build a massive company. The ambitious founder is always thinking about what to do next with the customer data they’ve earned access to through intake.

2) Automation idiosyncrasy. Contractors need to intake prospective client information in order to make a bid. For a roof repair, they inspect type, shingle layering, and pull city/local sizing data. A well designed LLM-based agent can do this extraction + automation, but the… https://t.co/UElYqGW0KN

One caveat — emotion. Sometimes AI performing the intake will degrade end user experience to the point where you lose revenue. In these cases, like personal injury, where empathy is needed, AI should be expressed assistively like a scribe.

1) Modality idiosyncrasy. Some intake experiences, like  in legal, require dynamic decisions based on client information. This is done by a paralegal or an admin with domain expertise, and requires concurrent proactive information extraction and selling of the lead. You cannot do… https://t.co/k7L9Claiq3

We see horizontal intake & scheduling products in the market adopt AI quickly — like Typeform — but we don’t believe they will capture the majority of value here. Good intake products are idiosyncratic to vertical and control where data goes. Two examples:
Services businesses suffer when they cannot effectively ingest information about new and existing customers & cannot close the loop on scheduling their service.
1/N Forms are king in Vertical SaaS, and today with domain-adaptable multimodal models, we have so many new ways to perform the core job of a form — Intake.

5/5 This article is a must-read for anyone interested in tech history, the smartphone wars, or stories of immigrant engineers shaping our digital world. Check it out here on Arena Magazine: https://t.co/gbMZBUusiI
4/5 I'm proud of my dad's contributions to tech history. Those colorful tiles weren't just cool to me - they were loved by many. Now, he's brought that expertise to his startup, @Esperdev.
3/5 In a great story about "what-ifs" in @mualphaxi's launch of @arenamagdotcom, we get a glimpse behind the curtain of the best phones that never quite won the market (for myriad reasons).

2/5 My dad was a core part of the team that dreamt up and architected the first real Windows smartphone. He spent 20 years tinkering with Windows CE and Windows Phone, from the first prototypes to the colorful tiles we remember. His box of old gadgets in our basement tells a long… https://t.co/z8GVtYSSp3

1/5 As a kid I always had (what I strongly believe) were the coolest phones. A sleek black HTC 7. A bright red Nokia Lumia 720. My dad's basement office was full of these devices (to my mother's chagrin).

6/6 Talent is the lifeblood of any business. In Tezi, we see a means of renewing the supply while strengthening, not distracting from, a company's fundamental purpose. Learn more in the blog we wrote here: https://t.co/ep3sB2yu3d

5/6 At the heart of Tezi is Max, their AI recruiting agent. Max handles end-to-end requirements for hiring managers and in-house recruiters, including sourcing, scheduling, screening, and reporting. All seamlessly integrated where users already work.

4/6 When we first spoke with @omrvp and @jas0njames about Tezi, we knew they were the perfect team to solve the EPD hiring problem in an AI-centric way, and extend to more enterprise job functions. RVP has a wealth of applied AI experience across modalities (at Covariant,… https://t.co/YiQMgCQv9g

3/6 Talent and recruiting have remained the dark arts of the enterprise. The high fiscal and operational costs of hiring attest to this ($250B in spend). It's an area crying out for better tech, but getting it right is critical.
2/6 Tezi is the autonomous AI recruiting partner set to revolutionize how companies hire. We’re thrilled to lead their $9M seed round alongside @AudaciousHQ

1/6 Hiring is hard. Every founder knows it. But why does it have to be hard AND stressful? Why do we drop leads, lose time on mundane recruiting work, and see pipeline velocity and quality degrade with scale? It doesn't have to be that way. Enter @TeziHQ 🚀

This goes without saying, they're extremely reliable. While your influencers are at a house party in Beverly Hills, ours are in a Midtown WeWork testing how lighting affects click through rates or replying to our clients on Slack.

So why the Eng, IB, Film? Because, if anything, we know the banker who spent 80 hours a week adjusting PowerPoint knows a thing or two about attention to detail. The engineers are hyper product aware; the filmmakers think deeply about content.
This means nuance is more important than ever. Content needs to be consistent yet narrowly different. Hooks and CTAs are bucketed both visually and in creative volume.

Our thesis is content can be built like software. Meaning, narrow variation testing in high volume will show you what the market wants. Let the algorithm do the work and users will guide the iteration for you.
This means two things: brand awareness matters much less and trust/relatability matters much more.
Social media flipped this slowly - then all at once. In the world where screens are literally strapped to faces, consumers have ad overload and highly-tuned bullshit meters.
Traditionally, media buying has been king. Inefficient channels meant agencies took a top down approach: broad brand content, narrowly targeted.

I run a social ad agency with @HamzaAlsamraee  and we only hire investment bankers, engineers, and filmmakers to make our content. Expensive way to hire? Yep. But we 10x results from other agencies, here's why👇

3. Measurement framework: there are many options to define the retention metric: N-day, unbounded, and bracketed retention. The Retention playbook by @Amplitude_HQ walks through what types of companies should consider each

2. Usage frequency: what's the usage frequency that you are observing with users that are retained? Is it weekly, monthly or daily? Based on that, the retention metric should be defined on those timeframes.

1. Define your critical event: the returning event should capture meaningful product activity. Ideally you can think of 1 or a set of events that you believe the user is getting real value from the product vs. broadly define login/any event as returning event.

💡The overall performance of a model depends on the trade-off between the overall subdomain cluster diversity, inter-sub-domain sample relevance, and intra-sub-domain semantic diversity in the samples selected using the sampling approach. https://t.co/br2KCFLDtm

Key Observations:
💡 A higher rate of increase of target domain sample diversity over the iterations results in better domain adaption. https://t.co/OsEmVxA0YB

📈 This leads to a significant gain in performance across two different training regimes compared to sampling few-shot data points uniformly at random. This with gradual training to new domains results in drastic improvements. https://t.co/ivrBwxbbAB

In this work, we proposed a novel clustering-based few-shot sampling approach that leverages intrinsically available sub-domain information as topics from the dataset to extract few-shot samples to be labeled from the target domains and be used for fine-tuning. https://t.co/l3hKwqsgmg

Great to see the effectiveness of introducing a diversity-based data selection strategy with iterative refinement for efficient fine-tuning. Interesting paper @simon_ycl!

We had similar findings in our EACL 2024 paper.

Why Newsletters Still Work:
- Owning your audience through newsletters is crucial.
- Newsletters allow for direct communication, unlike social media platforms.
- Be authentic and your subscribers will reward that.

Ship fast. Embrace imperfection:
- Don’t be afraid to launch a product that’s a 6/10.
- Ship it. Gather feedback and then immediately improve it.
- The opposite of a good launch is when nobody cares – attention is key.

Solution to Taking VC money:
- Be extremely transparent with investors on where the business is going.
- Ensure the cofounders maintain majority voting shares.

Anti VC ⍯ Don't Take VC Money
- Tyler is the most anti-VC guy that actively takes VC money. (I love that)
- Admits he needs it in order grow his business at rate he needs to compete

How to Grow Your Audience:
- Ask yourself who you your audience is and how you can provide value to them.
- Offering valuable content builds trust and rapport with your audience.
- Distribution increases your luck surface area.
- Just start writing

Early Adopters are Your Biggest Fans:
- The early adopters of your products will also be your fans and supporters, even when your product isn't perfect.
- Be blunt “Our product sucks, but we’re building it as quickly as possible.”
- Build and ship features for them

Mispriced Assets:
- A drastically underrated skill is story telling.
- This is why owning your audience is so critical. Get good at capturing their attention and keeping it.

Founder vs Early Employee:
- Biggest difference between being a founder and an early employee is how much equity you have in the business.
-You work just as hard. But as founder, you are accountable for the performance of the business.

yesterday i started adding them, hoping to test more today before merging.

now we had to just full send it

we merged the change and suddenly our database usage fell like a rock

(purple line is time of merge) https://t.co/aJ2KUJmBmR

then I realized:

planetscale doesn't have foreign keys, thus not automatically creating indexes on those fields.

I thought our @prisma schema had managed that...

but it turns out we started using prisma before it was in their docs

now it's a TOP 3 consideration https://t.co/unop3KfEGc

i previously contacted the great folks @planetscalehelp about query slowness and they mentioned indexing.

I knew indices' importance from MongoDB but thought they were less critical in relational databases.

luckily the last few days I was already spending most of my time investigating slow query performance

worst case queries were taking over TEN SECONDS 

this itself was causing plenty of problems and we needed a solution fast https://t.co/LwJOz0hMrA

turns out the amount of database reads we were doing was astronomical

AND had increased by an order of magnitude overnight

this was bad, so bad that planetscale wasn't able to autoscale fast enough to keep the site alive https://t.co/qVK95GgERH

worse than our redis problems were our database problems

we went suddenly from sub 100ms query times to suddenly having p50 times at nearly a second!! https://t.co/OXrvJeTLSB

the solution?

change how our backend used the redis cache: only spinning up a connection on graphql requests that needed them 

big shoutout to @joshsny on this one

first we realized our redis cache (on @upstash) was throttling us on the connection count

our plan only allowed for 1000 connections

now we had that many users with as many concurrent lambda's running, we were easily over the limit https://t.co/xAcJ7MD9J6

1000s of concurrent users brought @101dotxyz down today 😳

if you use @planetscaledata or redis with a serverless env, you should take a look at what happened...
